You are a fluent bilingual speaker of the English and Tamil languages, capable of translation between them. 
You are capable of code-switching, the common linguistic practice of alternating between two languages in the same utterance. 
Your task is to translate a given code-switched English and Tamil input sentence into a monolingual English version of the same sentence.
Learn from the following 9 examples of conversion from Tamil-English code-switching to monolingual English:

1. code-switched: "Trailer pakka super ah iruku but Rajesh neenga edhutha thungavanam padatha patha dha bayama iruku.." monolingual English: "The trailer looks nice but I am getting scared for the movie Thungavanam you've directed Rajesh"
2. code-switched: "PETTA trailer SUPER Rajnikanth Garu style we want Telugu release on January 10 Rajnikanth STYLE ADURS pakka MASS" monolingual English: "Rajnikanth Style in the Petta trailer is very good. We want this movie to be released in Telugu as well."
3. code-switched: " அடேங்கப்பா THALA speech ketukitte erukkanum pola erukku" monolingual English: "Wow we feel like we want to keep listening to Thala's speech"
4. code-switched: "Ungalukku jio phone tricks eppadi pannurathu? Thriyanuma appadina ennoda channel lai subecribe pannuga naanum thala fan" monolingual English: "if you want to know Jio phone tricks subscribe to my channel. I am also a Thala fan"
5. code-switched: "Rissing Star SK eppavum Trending Star" monolingual English: "SK is the new rising start and is always trending as well"
6. code-switched: "erukkalam I am not sure, just ges" monolingual English: "Maybe I am not sure, just guessing"
7. code-switched: "இப்படத்தை திரையிடுவதில் பிரச்சனை ஏதேனும் வந்தால் YouTube லேயே திரையிடுங்கள் என்னோட குடும்பத்தில் இருக்கும் 5 பேரின் டிக்கட் காசுகளையும் (with GST) நீங்கள் சொல்லும் Account numberku படம் திரையிடும் முன்பே அனுப்பி விடுகிறேன்." monolingual English: "If there is any issue with the movie screening, do screen it in Youtube. I will send the ticket price to the account number you tell me before the movie screening"
8. code-switched: " இது இப்பொ fashion ஆயிடு சாதி ஓழிங்கனு சொல்லிட்டு அதையே படமா பன்னிட்டு இருக்காங்க சரி முள்ளை முள்ளால் எடுக்கனும் அப்படி தான் நா இல்லனு சொல்லல அதுக்கு என் மற்ற சாதிய அசிங்க படுத்துரிங்க எங்க பாத்தாலும் தாழ்த்த பட்டவங்க சாதி வைச்சி sentiment ah எடுக்கிறிங்க என் மத்த சாதில இத மாரி நடக்களையா மாறட்டும் சமுகம் மாறட்டும் சாதி மதம்" monolingual English: "It's becoming a fashion these days to protest against caste system and use that as a baseline to make movies. Yes we should remove a thorn with a thorn I agree but that does not mean you talk bad/ill about another caste. Everywhere sentiment scenes are made using the lower caste, but don't you think this is happening with other castes too? Let the society change"
9. code-switched: "0:17 Nadodigal 2 ennu per wekkaama Aambala 2 endu watchi irukalam!! Ennadaa panni watchirukinga!! Perukum Trailaerukum connectione illa!!! Another sequel flop!" monolingual English: "Instead of naming the movie as Nadodigal 2 they could have named it Aambala 2. What have you guys done, there is no relation between the trailer and the movie title. Another sequel flop!!"

user_question:
Translate the following code-switched text into monolingual English:
code-switched: "Thala na massss.  By தளபதி ரசிகன்" monolingual English:
model_response:
Monolingual English: "The leader is amazing. By a fan of the commander."  

(Note: "Thala" and "தளபதி" (Thalapathi) are titles referring to a leader/commander, often used as nicknames for iconic figures like actors or heroes in Tamil cinema. "Massss" conveys admiration in a stylish, exaggerated way—common in Tamil pop culture.)

system_prompt:
1-lng
Code-switching and code-mixing refer to the intra- and inter-sentential alternation between two or more languages or language varieties within a single discourse. From a morphosyntactic perspective, these phenomena are governed by identifiable grammatical constraints that regulate where and how switching may occur without compromising grammaticality.
One of the most widely cited constraints is the Equivalence Constraint (Poplack, 1980), which posits that code-switching tends to occur at points in discourse where the surface structures of both languages are congruent or share equivalent word order. This ensures that the syntactic rules of both languages are respected, avoiding ungrammatical constructions. For example, in Spanish-English switching, a switch between “I saw her en la tienda” is permissible, as both English and Spanish permit a noun phrase in post-verbal object position. However, switching within a compound verb or at a point where constituent order differs cross-linguistically is often blocked.
The Matrix Language Frame Model (Myers-Scotton, 1993) further formalizes this by distinguishing between a matrix language (ML) and an embedded language (EL). The ML provides the morphosyntactic frame of the sentence, determining word order, functional morphology, and system morphemes, while content morphemes (lexical items) may be inserted from the EL. Importantly, system morphemes (such as inflectional affixes or function words) are typically drawn from the ML, due to their language-specific syntactic dependencies.
Another critical constraint is the Functional Head Constraint (Belazi, Rubin, and Toribio, 1994), which restricts switching between a functional head (e.g., determiner, complementizer, tense) and its complement. For instance, switching between a determiner and noun in languages with differing determiner-noun agreement systems (e.g., French-English: “the voiture”) is less acceptable than switching at noun phrase boundaries.
In addition, morphological compatibility is essential; bound morphemes rarely cross language boundaries. A switch is generally not allowed when a morpheme from one language would attach to a root from another. This holds especially for fusional languages, where morphology is tightly integrated with syntax.
Cross-linguistically, typological similarity between the languages involved influences the range of acceptable switch points. For instance, in VSO languages (e.g., Arabic) versus SVO languages (e.g., English), constituent structure mismatches constrain the syntactic loci where switches may occur. Nonetheless, bilingual speakers develop internalized rules that allow them to exploit structurally congruent points of alignment for switching, creating hybrid constructions that remain grammatically well-formed within both systems.
Your task is to translate a given code-switched English and Tamil input sentence into a monolingual English version of the same sentence.
Learn from the following example of conversion from Tamil-English code-switching to monolingual English:

1. code-switched: "Trailer pakka super ah iruku but Rajesh neenga edhutha thungavanam padatha patha dha bayama iruku.." monolingual English: "The trailer looks nice but I am getting scared for the movie Thungavanam you've directed Rajesh"

user_question:
Translate the following code-switched text into monolingual English:
code-switched: "Thala na massss.  By தளபதி ரசிகன்" monolingual English:
model_response:
Monolingual English: "The leader is amazing. By a fan of Thalapathy."

"தளபதி" (Thalapathy) is a title meaning "commander" or "leader," often associated with the actor Vijay. The phrase is a fan's enthusiastic praise.)
